chunk: in 2023 in targeted intrusions against military and government entities in the Netherlands along with other victims, [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) was disclosed in early 2024, with a high confidence assessment linking this malware to a state-sponsored entity in the People's Republic of China. [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is delivered after gaining access to a FortiGate device, with in-the-wild observations linked to exploitation of CVE-2022-42475. The name [COATHANGER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1105) is based on a unique string in the malware used to encrypt configuration files on disk: “She took his coat and hung it up”.(Citation: NCSC-NL COATHANGER Feb 2024) Platforms: Linux, Network

entities.name: COATHANGER
entities.description: COATHANGER is a malware linked to targeted intrusions against military and government entities in the Netherlands, associated with a state-sponsored entity in the People's Republic of China.

entities.name: NETHERLANDS
entities.description: The Netherlands is a country that has been targeted by the COATHANGER malware in intrusions against military and government entities.

entities.name: PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA
entities.description: The People's Republic of China is identified as the state-sponsored entity linked to the COATHANGER malware.

entities.name: CVE-2022-42475
entities.description: CVE-2022-42475 is a vulnerability exploited to gain access to FortiGate devices, facilitating the delivery of the COATHANGER malware.

entities.name: NCSC-NL
entities.description: NCSC-NL is the National Cyber Security Centre in the Netherlands that provided information regarding the COATHANGER malware in February 2024.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Container Service. Their names are as follows:
* Software Configuration 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.name: SOFTWARE CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that involves implementing configuration changes to software to reduce security risks.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing user accounts, including their creation, modification, use, and permissions.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods are strategies or techniques used to reduce or eliminate security risks associated with various attack techniques.

chunk:
There are 8 software using the attack technique called Winlogon Helper DLL. Their names are as follows:
* Gazer
* DarkTortilla
* Dipsind
* Bazar
* Remexi
* Revenge RAT
* KeyBoy
* Cannon

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Gazer
Software description: [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) is a backdoor used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2016. (Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkTortilla
Software description: [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter that has been possibly active since at least August 2015. [DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has been used to deliver popular information stealers, RATs, and payloads such as [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), AsyncRat, [NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336), RedLine, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154), and Metasploit.(Citation: Secureworks DarkTortilla Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dipsind
Software description: [Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) is a malware family of backdoors that appear to be used exclusively by [PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068). (Citation: Microsoft PLATINUM April 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bazar
Software description: [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) is a downloader and backdoor that has been used since at least April 2020, with infections primarily against professional services, healthcare, manufacturing, IT, logistics and travel companies across the US and Europe. [Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) reportedly has ties to [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) campaigns and can be used to deploy additional malware, including ransomware, and to steal sensitive data.(Citation: Cybereason Bazar July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Revenge RAT
Software description: [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) is a freely available remote access tool written in .NET (C#).(Citation: Cylance Shaheen Nov 2018)(Citation: Cofense RevengeRAT Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KeyBoy
Software description: [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) is malware that has been used in targeted campaigns against members of the Tibetan Parliament in 2016.(Citation: CitizenLab KeyBoy Nov 2016)(Citation: PWC KeyBoys Feb 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cannon
Software description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018. (Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: Gazer is a backdoor software used by Turla since at least 2016, operating on Windows platforms.

entities.name: DARKTORTILLA
entities.description: DarkTortilla is a highly configurable .NET-based crypter, possibly active since at least August 2015, used to deliver various malware on Windows platforms.

entities.name: DIPSIND
entities.description: Dipsind is a malware family of backdoors used exclusively by PLATINUM, operating on Windows platforms.

entities.name: BAZAR
entities.description: Bazar is a downloader and backdoor used since at least April 2020, targeting various sectors across the US and Europe, operating on Windows platforms.

entities.name: REMEXI
entities.description: Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in the C programming language.

entities.name: CANNON

chunk:
There are 3 software using the attack technique called System Firmware. Their names are as follows:
* LoJax
* Trojan.Mebromi
* Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: LoJax
Software description: [LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) is a UEFI rootkit used by [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) to persist remote access software on targeted systems.(Citation: ESET LoJax Sept 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Trojan.Mebromi
Software description: [Trojan.Mebromi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0001) is BIOS-level malware that takes control of the victim before MBR. (Citation: Ge 2011)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit
Software description: [Hacking Team UEFI Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0047) is a rootkit developed by the company Hacking Team as a method of persistence for remote access software. (Citation: TrendMicro Hacking Team UEFI)
Platforms: None

entities.name: APT28
entities.description: APT28 is a cyber espionage group known for using various malware, including LoJax, to target systems.

chunk: There are 14 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called Boot or Logon Autostart Execution. Their names are as follows: * Shortcut Modification * Kernel Modules and Extensions * Re-opened Applications * Winlogon Helper DLL * Security Support Provider * Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder * LSASS Driver * Print Processors * Active Setup * Login Items * XDG Autostart Entries * Time Providers * Authentication Package * Port Monitors The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows: Attack technique name: *** Attack technique description: *** Platforms: *** These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target. Attack technique name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution Attack technique description: Adversaries may configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems. Operating systems may have mechanisms for automatically running a program on system boot or account logon.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key)(Citation: MSDN Authentication Packages)(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider)(Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013)(Citation: Linux Kernel Programming) These mechanisms may include automatically executing programs that are placed in specially designated directories or are referenced by repositories that store configuration information, such as the Windows Registry. An adversary may achieve the same goal by modifying or extending features of the kernel. Since some boot or logon autostart programs run with higher privileges, an adversary may leverage these to elevate privileges. Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows, Network Attack technique name: Shortcut Modification Attack technique description: Adversaries may create or modify shortcuts that can execute a program during system boot or user login. Shortcuts or symbolic links are used to reference other files or programs that will be opened or executed when the shortcut is clicked or executed by a system startup process. Adversaries may abuse shortcuts in the startup folder to execute their tools and achieve persistence.(Citation: Shortcut for Persistence ) Although often used as payloads in an infection chain (e.g. [Spearphishing Attachment](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001)), adversaries may also create a new shortcut as a means of indirection, while also abusing [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the malicious shortcut appear as a legitimate program. Adversaries can also edit the target path or entirely replace an existing shortcut so their malware will be executed instead of the intended legitimate program. Shortcuts can also be abused to establish persistence by implementing other methods. For example, LNK browser extensions may be modified (e.g. [Browser Extensions](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1176)) to persistently launch malware. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Kernel Modules and Extensions Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot. Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) are pieces of code that can be loaded and unloaded into the kernel upon demand. They extend the functionality of the kernel without the need to reboot the system. For example, one type of module is the device driver, which allows the kernel to access hardware connected to the system.(Citation: Linux Kernel Programming)  When used maliciously, LKMs can be a type of kernel-mode [Rootkit](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1014) that run with the highest operating system privilege (Ring 0).(Citation: Linux Kernel Module Programming Guide) Common features of LKM based rootkits include: hiding itself, selective hiding of files, processes and network activity, as well as log tampering, providing authenticated backdoors, and enabling root access to non-privileged users.(Citation: iDefense Rootkit Overview) Kernel extensions, also called kext, are used in macOS to load functionality onto a system similar to LKMs for Linux. Since the kernel is responsible for enforcing security and the kernel extensions run as apart of the kernel, kexts are not governed by macOS security policies. Kexts are loaded and unloaded through kextload and kextunload commands. Kexts need to be signed with a developer ID that is granted privileges by Apple allowing it to sign Kernel extensions. Developers without these privileges may still sign kexts but they will not load unless SIP is disabled. If SIP is enabled, the kext signature is verified before being added to the AuxKC.(Citation: System and kernel extensions in macOS) Since macOS Catalina 10.15, kernel extensions have been deprecated in favor of System Extensions. However, kexts are still allowed as "Legacy System Extensions" since there is no System Extension for Kernel Programming Interfaces.(Citation: Apple Kernel Extension Deprecation) Adversaries can use LKMs and kexts to conduct [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) and/or [Privilege Escalation](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0004) on a system. Examples have been found in the wild, and there are some relevant open source projects as well.(Citation: Volatility Phalanx2)(Citation: CrowdStrike Linux Rootkit)(Citation: GitHub Reptile)(Citation: GitHub Diamorphine)(Citation: RSAC 2015 San Francisco Patrick Wardle)(Citation: Synack Secure Kernel Extension Broken)(Citation: Securelist Ventir)(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap) Platforms: macOS, Linux Attack technique name: Re-opened Applications Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify plist files to automatically run an application

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON AUTOSTART EXECUTION
entities.description: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution is an attack technique where adversaries configure system settings to automatically execute a program during system boot or logon to maintain persistence or gain higher-level privileges on compromised systems.

entities.name: SHORTCUT MODIFICATION
entities.description: Shortcut Modification is an attack technique where adversaries create or modify shortcuts that can execute a program during system boot or user login, often used to achieve persistence.

entities.name: KERNEL MODULES AND EXTENSIONS
entities.description: Kernel Modules and Extensions is an attack technique where adversaries modify the kernel to automatically execute programs on system boot, using Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) or kernel extensions (kexts) in macOS.

entities.name: RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS
entities.description: Re-opened Applications is an attack technique where adversaries modify plist files to automatically run an application during system boot or user login.

entities.name: REGISTRY RUN KEYS / STARTUP FOLDER
entities.description: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder is a method used by adversaries to configure programs to run automatically at system startup by modifying the Windows Registry or placing programs in the startup folder.

entities.name: LSASS DRIVER
entities.description: LSASS Driver is a process that handles security policies and user authentication in Windows, which can be targeted by adversaries to maintain persistence.

entities.name: PRINT PROCESSORS
entities.description: Print Processors are components that manage print jobs in Windows, which can be exploited by adversaries to execute malicious code during the printing process.

entities.name: ACTIVE SETUP
entities.description: Active Setup is a Windows feature that allows applications to run scripts or programs when a user logs in, which can be abused by adversaries for persistence.

entities.name: LOGIN ITEMS
entities.description: Login Items are applications that are set to open automatically when a user logs into macOS, which can be manipulated by adversaries to achieve persistence.

entities.name: XDG AUTOSTART ENTRIES
entities.description: XDG Autostart Entries are used in Linux environments to automatically start applications when a user logs in, which can be exploited by adversaries for persistence.

entities.name: TIME PROVIDERS
entities.description: Time Providers are components that manage time synchronization in operating systems, which can be targeted by adversaries to maintain control over system time settings.

entities.name: AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE
entities.description: Authentication Package is a component that handles user authentication in Windows, which can be manipulated by adversaries to gain unauthorized access.

entities.name: PORT MONITORS
entities.description: Port Monitors are components that manage communication between the operating system and printers, which can be exploited by adversaries to execute malicious code.)<|COMPLETE|>

key="d1">Time Providers are components that manage time synchronization in operating systems, which can be targeted by adversaries to maintain control over system time settings.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Authentication Package is a component that handles user authentication in Windows, which can be manipulated by adversaries to gain unauthorized access.</data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <node id="PORT MONITORS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Port Monitors are components that manage communication between the operating system and printers, which can be exploited by adversaries to execute malicious code.)<|COMPLETE|></data>      <data key="d2">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </node>    <edge source="BOOT OR LOGON AUTOSTART EXECUTION" target="SHORTCUT MODIFICATION">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques involve methods to achieve persistence by executing programs during system boot or user login</data>      <data key="d5">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BOOT OR LOGON AUTOSTART EXECUTION" target="KERNEL MODULES AND EXTENSIONS">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques are focused on executing programs at system boot to maintain persistence and elevate privileges</data>      <data key="d5">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </edge>    <edge source="BOOT OR LOGON AUTOSTART EXECUTION" target="RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques aim to automatically run applications during system boot or user login to maintain persistence</data>      <data key="d5">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SHORTCUT MODIFICATION" target="KERNEL MODULES AND EXTENSIONS">      <data key="d3">6.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques are used by adversaries to achieve persistence through different methods of execution during system boot</data>      <data key="d5">1b3ee106fb26cba835f5fef34c929d64</data>    </edge>    <edge source="SHORTCUT MODIFICATION" target="RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS">      <data key="d3">5.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both MODULES AND EXTENSIONS" target="RE-OPENED APPLICATIONS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Both techniques can be used to achieve persistence on a system by executing programs at boot chunk: 2)(Citation: CrowdStrike Linux Rootkit)(Citation: GitHub Reptile)(Citation: GitHub Diamorphine)(Citation: RSAC 2015 San Francisco Patrick Wardle)(Citation: Synack Secure Kernel Extension Broken)(Citation: Securelist Ventir)(Citation: Trend Micro Skidmap) Platforms: macOS, Linux Attack technique name: Re-opened Applications Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify plist files to automatically run an application when a user logs in. When a user logs out or restarts via the macOS Graphical User Interface (GUI), a prompt is provided to the user with a checkbox to "Reopen windows when logging back in".(Citation: Re-Open windows on Mac) When selected, all applications currently open are added to a property list file named com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist within the ~/Library/Preferences/ByHost directory.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter) Applications listed in this file are automatically reopened upon the user’s next logon. Adversaries can establish [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003) by adding a malicious application path to the com.apple.loginwindow.[UUID].plist file to execute payloads when a user logs in. Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Winlogon Helper DLL Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse features of Winlogon to execute DLLs and/or executables when a user logs in. Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete. Registry entries in HKLM\Software[\\Wow6432Node\\]\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon.(Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013) Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables. Specifically, the following subkeys have been known to be possibly vulnerable to abuse: (Citation: Cylance Reg Persistence Sept 2013) * Winlogon\Notify - points to notification package DLLs that handle Winlogon events * Winlogon\Userinit - points to userinit.exe, the user initialization program executed when a user logs on * Winlogon\Shell - points to explorer.exe, the system shell executed when a user logs on Adversaries may take advantage of these features to repeatedly execute malicious code and establish persistence. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Security Support Provider Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse security support providers (SSPs) to execute DLLs when the system boots. Windows SSP DLLs are loaded into the Local Security Authority (LSA) process at system start. Once loaded into the LSA, SSP DLLs have access to encrypted and plaintext passwords that are stored in Windows, such as any logged-on user's Domain password or smart card PINs. The SSP configuration is stored in two Registry keys: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\Security Packages and HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\OSConfig\Security Packages. An adversary may modify these Registry keys to add new SSPs, which will be loaded the next time the system boots, or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called.(Citation: Graeber 2014) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder Attack technique description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key. Adding an entry to the "run keys" in the Registry or startup folder will cause the program referenced to be executed when a user logs in.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. The following run keys are created by default on Windows systems: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce Run keys may exist under multiple hives.(Citation: Microsoft Wow6432Node 2018)(Citation: Malwarebytes Wow6432Node 2016) The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx is also available but is not created by default on Windows Vista and newer. Registry run key entries can reference programs directly or list them as a dependency.(Citation: Microsoft Run Key) For example, it is possible to load a DLL at logon using a "Depend" key with RunOnceEx: reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder

chunk: : reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnceEx\0001\Depend /v 1 /d "C:\temp\evil[.]dll" (Citation: Oddvar Moe RunOnceEx Mar 2018) Placing a program within a startup folder will also cause that program to execute when a user logs in. There is a startup folder location for individual user accounts as well as a system-wide startup folder that will be checked regardless of which user account logs in. The startup folder path for the current user is C:\Users\\[Username]\AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup. The startup folder path for all users is C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\StartUp. The following Registry keys can be used to set startup folder items for persistence: * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\User Shell Folders The following Registry keys can control automatic startup of services during boot: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServicesOnce * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunServices Using policy settings to specify startup programs creates corresponding values in either of two Registry keys: * HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run * HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer\Run Programs listed in the load value of the registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows run automatically for the currently logged-on user. By default, the multistring BootExecute value of the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager is set to autocheck autochk *. This value causes Windows, at startup, to check the file-system integrity of the hard disks if the system has been shut down abnormally. Adversaries can add other programs or processes to this registry value which will automatically launch at boot. Adversaries can use these configuration locations to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: LSASS Driver Attack technique description: Adversaries may modify or add LSASS drivers to obtain persistence on compromised systems. The Windows security subsystem is a set of components that manage and enforce the security policy for a computer or domain. The Local Security Authority (LSA) is the main component responsible for local security policy and user authentication. The LSA includes multiple dynamic link libraries (DLLs) associated with various other security functions, all of which run in the context of the LSA Subsystem Service (LSASS) lsass.exe process.(Citation: Microsoft Security Subsystem) Adversaries may target LSASS drivers to obtain persistence. By either replacing or adding illegitimate drivers (e.g., [Hijack Execution Flow](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574)), an adversary can use LSA operations to continuously execute malicious payloads. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Print Processors Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse print processors to run malicious DLLs during system boot for persistence and/or privilege escalation. Print processors are DLLs that are loaded by the print spooler service, `spoolsv.exe`, during boot.(Citation: Microsoft Intro Print Processors) Adversaries may abuse the print spooler service by adding print processors that load malicious DLLs at startup. A print processor can be installed through the AddPrintProcessor API call with an account that has SeLoadDriverPrivilege enabled. Alternatively, a print processor can be registered to the print spooler service by adding the HKLM\SYSTEM\\[CurrentControlSet or ControlSet001]\Control\Print\Environments\\[Windows architecture: e.g., Windows x64]\Print Processors\\[user defined]\Driver Registry key that points to the DLL. For the malicious print processor to be correctly installed, the payload must be located in the dedicated system print-processor directory, that can be found with the GetPrintProcessorDirectory API call, or referenced via a relative path from this directory.(Citation: Microsoft AddPrintProcessor May 2018) After the print processors are installed, the print spooler service, which starts during boot, must be restarted in order for them to run.(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020) The print spooler service runs under SYSTEM level permissions, therefore print processors installed by an adversary may run under elevated privileges. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Active Setup Attack

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that supports various functionalities including startup programs and registry modifications for persistence.

entities.name: LSASS
entities.description: The Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) is a process in Windows responsible for enforcing security policies and user authentication.

entities.name: SPOLSV
entities.description: The print spooler service (spoolsv.exe) in Windows manages print jobs and can be exploited to run malicious DLLs during system boot.

entities.name: MALWARE
entities.description: Malware refers to malicious software designed to disrupt, damage, or gain unauthorized access to computer systems.

entities.name: PRINT PROCESSORS
entities.description: Print processors are DLLs loaded by the print spooler service during boot, which can be abused to run malicious code.

entities.name: REGISTRY KEYS
entities.description: Registry keys in Windows are used to configure system settings, including startup programs and services.

entities.name: ADVERSARIES
entities.description: Adversaries are individuals or groups that exploit vulnerabilities in systems to execute malicious activities.

entities.name: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
entities.description: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration settings for the local machine, affecting all users.

entities.name: BOOTEXECUTE
entities.description: BootExecute is a registry value that determines which programs run automatically at system startup.

entities.name: AUTOCHECK
entities.description: Autocheck is a default value in the BootExecute registry key that checks the file-system integrity of hard disks at startup.

entities.name: USER SHELL FOLDERS
entities.description: User Shell Folders are registry keys that define the locations of various user-specific folders in Windows.

entities.name: POLICIES
entities.description: Policies in Windows are settings that can control the behavior of the operating system, including startup programs.

chunk: or referenced via a relative path from this directory.(Citation: Microsoft AddPrintProcessor May 2018) After the print processors are installed, the print spooler service, which starts during boot, must be restarted in order for them to run.(Citation: ESET PipeMon May 2020) The print spooler service runs under SYSTEM level permissions, therefore print processors installed by an adversary may run under elevated privileges. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Active Setup Attack technique description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a Registry key to the Active Setup of the local machine. Active Setup is a Windows mechanism that is used to execute programs when a user logs in. The value stored in the Registry key will be executed after a user logs into the computer.(Citation: Klein Active Setup 2010) These programs will be executed under the context of the user and will have the account's associated permissions level. Adversaries may abuse Active Setup by creating a key under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Active Setup\Installed Components\ and setting a malicious value for StubPath. This value will serve as the program that will be executed when a user logs into the computer.(Citation: Mandiant Glyer APT 2010)(Citation: Citizenlab Packrat 2015)(Citation: FireEye CFR Watering Hole 2012)(Citation: SECURELIST Bright Star 2015)(Citation: paloalto Tropic Trooper 2016) Adversaries can abuse these components to execute malware, such as remote access tools, to maintain persistence through system reboots. Adversaries may also use [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to make the Registry entries look as if they are associated with legitimate programs. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Login Items Attack technique description: Adversaries may add login items to execute upon user login to gain persistence or escalate privileges. Login items are applications, documents, folders, or server connections that are automatically launched when a user logs in.(Citation: Open Login Items Apple) Login items can be added via a shared file list or Service Management Framework.(Citation: Adding Login Items) Shared file list login items can be set using scripting languages such as [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002), whereas the Service Management Framework uses the API call SMLoginItemSetEnabled. Login items installed using the Service Management Framework leverage launchd, are not visible in the System Preferences, and can only be removed by the application that created them.(Citation: Adding Login Items)(Citation: SMLoginItemSetEnabled Schroeder 2013) Login items created using a shared file list are visible in System Preferences, can hide the application when it launches, and are executed through LaunchServices, not launchd, to open applications, documents, or URLs without using Finder.(Citation: Launch Services Apple Developer) Users and applications use login items to configure their user environment to launch commonly used services or applications, such as email, chat, and music applications. Adversaries can utilize [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) and [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) calls to create a login item to spawn malicious executables.(Citation: ELC Running at startup) Prior to version 10.5 on macOS, adversaries can add login items by using [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002) to send an Apple events to the “System Events” process, which has an AppleScript dictionary for manipulating login items.(Citation: Login Items AE) Adversaries can use a command such as tell application “System Events” to make login item at end with properties /path/to/executable.(Citation: Startup Items Eclectic)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: Add List Remove Login Items Apple Script) This command adds the path of the malicious executable to the login item file list located in ~/Library/Application Support/com.apple.backgroundtaskmanagementagent/backgrounditems.btm.(Citation: Startup Items Eclectic) Adversaries can also use login items to launch executables that can be used to control the victim system remotely or as a means to gain privilege escalation by prompting for user credentials.(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)(Citation: objsee netwire backdoor 2019) Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: XDG Autostart Entries Attack technique description: Adversaries may add or modify XDG Autostart Entries to execute malicious programs or commands when a user’s desktop environment is loaded at login. XDG Autostart entries are available for any XDG-compliant Linux system. XDG Autostart entries use Desktop Entry files (`.desktop`) to configure the user’s desktop environment upon user login. These configuration files determine what applications launch upon user login, define associated applications to open specific file types, and define applications used to open removable media.(Citation: Free Desktop Application Autostart Feb 2006)(Citation: Free Desktop Entry Keys) Adversaries may abuse this feature to establish persistence by adding a path to a malicious binary or command to the `Exec` directive in the `.desktop` configuration file. When the user’s desktop environment is loaded at user login, the `.desktop` files located in the XDG Autostart directories are automatically executed. System-wide Autostart entries are located in the `/etc/xdg/autostart` directory while the user

entities.description: XDG Autostart Entries are configuration files used in Linux systems to determine what applications launch upon user login, which can be manipulated by adversaries to execute malicious programs.

chunk: 2006)(Citation: Free Desktop Entry Keys) Adversaries may abuse this feature to establish persistence by adding a path to a malicious binary or command to the `Exec` directive in the `.desktop` configuration file. When the user’s desktop environment is loaded at user login, the `.desktop` files located in the XDG Autostart directories are automatically executed. System-wide Autostart entries are located in the `/etc/xdg/autostart` directory while the user entries are located in the `~/.config/autostart` directory. Adversaries may combine this technique with [Masquerading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036) to blend malicious Autostart entries with legitimate programs.(Citation: Red Canary Netwire Linux 2022) Platforms: Linux Attack technique name: Time Providers Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse time providers to execute DLLs when the system boots. The Windows Time service (W32Time) enables time synchronization across and within domains.(Citation: Microsoft W32Time Feb 2018) W32Time time providers are responsible for retrieving time stamps from hardware/network resources and outputting these values to other network clients.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) Time providers are implemented as dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) that are registered in the subkeys of `HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\W32Time\TimeProviders\`.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) The time provider manager, directed by the service control manager, loads and starts time providers listed and enabled under this key at system startup and/or whenever parameters are changed.(Citation: Microsoft TimeProvider) Adversaries may abuse this architecture to establish persistence, specifically by creating a new arbitrarily named subkey pointing to a malicious DLL in the `DllName` value. Administrator privileges are required for time provider registration, though execution will run in context of the Local Service account.(Citation: Github W32Time Oct 2017) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Authentication Package Attack technique description: Adversaries may abuse authentication packages to execute DLLs when the system boots. Windows authentication package DLLs are loaded by the Local Security Authority (LSA) process at system start. They provide support for multiple logon processes and multiple security protocols to the operating system.(Citation: MSDN Authentication Packages) Adversaries can use the autostart mechanism provided by LSA authentication packages for persistence by placing a reference to a binary in the Windows Registry location HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa\ with the key value of "Authentication Packages"=<target binary>. The binary will then be executed by the system when the authentication packages are loaded. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Port Monitors Attack technique description: Adversaries may use port monitors to run an adversary supplied DLL during system boot for persistence or privilege escalation. A port monitor can be set through the AddMonitor API call to set a DLL to be loaded at startup.(Citation: AddMonitor) This DLL can be located in C:\Windows\System32 and will be loaded and run by the print spooler service, `spoolsv.exe`, under SYSTEM level permissions on boot.(Citation: Bloxham) Alternatively, an arbitrary DLL can be loaded if permissions allow writing a fully-qualified pathname for that DLL to the `Driver` value of an existing or new arbitrarily named subkey of HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors. The Registry key contains entries for the following: * Local Port * Standard TCP/IP Port * USB Monitor * WSD Port Platforms: Windows

entities.name: XDG AUTOSTART
entities.description: XDG Autostart is a system for managing desktop entries that are automatically executed at user login in Linux environments.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft that supports various functionalities including time synchronization and security protocols.

entities.name: LSA
entities.description: Local Security Authority (LSA) is a process in Windows that manages security policies and authentication packages.

entities.name: SPOLSV.EXE
entities.description: Spoolsv.exe is the print spooler service in Windows that manages print jobs and can load DLLs during system boot.

entities.name: AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE
entities.description: Authentication packages are DLLs loaded by the LSA process at system start to support logon processes and security protocols.

entities.name: TIME PROVIDERS
entities.description: Time providers are dynamic-link libraries that enable time synchronization across domains in Windows.

entities.name: PORT MONITORS
entities.description: Port monitors are mechanisms in Windows that allow DLLs to be executed during system boot for persistence or privilege escalation.

entities.name: EXEC DIRECTIVE
entities.description: The Exec directive in a .desktop configuration file specifies the command to execute when the desktop environment is loaded.

entities.name: DYNAMIC-LINK LIBRARIES
entities.description: Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) are files that contain code and data that can be used by multiple programs simultaneously, often used for executing functions in Windows.

entities.name: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
entities.description: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration information for the local machine, including system settings and installed software.

entities.name: HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\LSA
entities.description: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa is a registry path in Windows where authentication packages are registered for execution during system startup.

entities.name: HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\PRINT\MONITORS
entities.description: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors is a registry path in Windows that contains entries for print monitors, which can load DLLs at startup.

key="d1">XDG Autostart is a system for managing desktop entries that are automatically executed at user login in Linux environments.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="WINDOWS">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft that supports various functionalities including time synchronization and security protocols.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="LSA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Local Security Authority (LSA) is a process in Windows that manages security policies and authentication packages.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="SPOLSV.EXE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Spoolsv.exe is the print spooler service in Windows that manages print jobs and can load DLLs during system boot.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Authentication packages are DLLs loaded by the LSA process at system start to support logon processes and security protocols.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="TIME PROVIDERS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Time providers are dynamic-link libraries that enable time synchronization across domains in Windows.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="PORT MONITORS">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Port monitors are mechanisms in Windows that allow DLLs to be executed during system boot for persistence or privilege escalation.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="EXEC DIRECTIVE">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">The Exec directive in a .desktop configuration file specifies the command to execute when the desktop environment is loaded.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="DYNAMIC-LINK LIBRARIES">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) are files that contain code and data that can be used by multiple programs simultaneously, often used for executing functions in Windows.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a registry hive in Windows that contains configuration information for the local machine, including system settings and installed software.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\LSA">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa is a registry path in Windows where authentication packages are registered for execution during system startup.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\PRINT\MONITORS">      <data key="d0">GEO</data>      <data key="d1">HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors is a registry path in Windows that contains entries for print monitors, which can load DLLs at startup.</data>      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <node id="MALICIOUS BINARY">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </node>    <edge source="XDG AUTOSTART" target="WINDOWS">      <data key="d3">3.0</data>      <data key="d4">XDG Autostart is a feature in Linux that parallels functionalities found in Windows for managing startup processes.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="LSA">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">The Local Security Authority (LSA) is a critical component of Windows that handles authentication and security protocols.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="SPOLSV.EXE">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Spoolsv.exe is a service in Windows that operates under the system's permissions and can execute DLLs at startup.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="AUTHENTICATION PACKAGE">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">Authentication packages are integral to Windows' security framework, loaded by the LSA during system start.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="TIME PROVIDERS">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">Time providers are part of the Windows architecture that manages time synchronization and are executed at boot.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="PORT MONITORS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">Port monitors in Windows allow for the execution of DLLs during system boot, similar to other autostart mechanisms.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="DYNAMIC-LINK LIBRARIES">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">Dynamic-link libraries (DLLs) are a fundamental part of the Windows operating system, enabling various functionalities and applications to run.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE is a critical component of the Windows registry that stores system-wide settings and configurations.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\LSA">      <data key="d3">9.0</data>      <data key="d4">The registry path HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa is essential for the operation of authentication packages in Windows.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="WINDOWS" target="HKLM\SYSTEM\CURRENTCONTROLSET\CONTROL\PRINT\MONITORS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">The registry path HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Print\Monitors is used by Windows to manage print monitor settings and DLL execution.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>    <edge source="EXEC DIRECTIVE" target="MALICIOUS BINARY">      <data key="d3">7.0</data>      <data key="d4">Malicious binaries can be executed through the Exec directive in .desktop files, allowing adversaries to establish persistence.</data>      <data key="d5">07969a79a1dda4040e5d75c67b167c1d</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Run Virtual Instance. Their names are as follows:
* Disable or Remove Feature or Program 
* Execution Prevention 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

entities.name: RUN VIRTUAL INSTANCE
entities.description: Run Virtual Instance is an attack technique that can be mitigated through specific methods to prevent exploitation.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: This mitigation method involves removing or denying access to unnecessary software to prevent potential abuse by adversaries.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: This mitigation method blocks the execution of code on a system through application control and/or script blocking.

entities.name: ATTACK TECHNIQUE
entities.description: An attack technique refers to a specific method used by adversaries to exploit vulnerabilities in a system, exemplified by Run Virtual Instance.

chunk:
There are 1 software using the attack technique called Adversary-in-the-Middle. Their names are as follows:
* Dok

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Dok
Software description: [Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that is able to collect user credentials and install a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic (i.e. [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557)).(Citation: objsee mac malware 2017)(Citation: hexed osx.dok analysis 2019)(Citation: CheckPoint Dok)
Platforms: macOS

entities.name: DOK
entities.description: Dok is a Trojan application disguised as a .zip file that collects user credentials and installs a malicious proxy server to redirect a user's network traffic, operating on macOS.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, which is the platform on which the Dok software operates.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 9 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called OS Credential Dumping. Their names are as follows:
* Encrypt Sensitive Information 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Password Policies 
* User Training 
* Privileged Account Management 
* Privileged Process Integrity 
* Credential Access Protection 
* Active Directory Configuration 
* Operating System Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Password Policies
Mitigation method description: Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Process Integrity
Mitigation method description: Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.

Mitigation method name: Credential Access Protection
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a mitigation method that protects sensitive information with strong encryption.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems.

entities.name: PASSWORD POLICIES
entities.description: Password Policies is a mitigation method that sets and enforces secure password policies for accounts.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method that trains users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by adversaries.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED PROCESS INTEGRITY
entities.description: Privileged Process Integrity is a mitigation method that protects high-privilege processes that can interact with critical system components.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL ACCESS PROTECTION
entities.description: Credential Access Protection is a mitigation method that prevents successful credential access by adversaries.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Active Directory Configuration is a mitigation method that configures Active Directory to prevent certain techniques.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that makes configuration changes to harden the system against techniques.

entities.name: OS CREDENTIAL DUMPING
entities.description: OS Credential Dumping is an attack technique that involves extracting credentials from operating systems to gain unauthorized access.

There are 0 sub attack techniques of the attack technique called External Remote Services. Their names are as follows:

The following content describes information about the attack techniques. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: External Remote Services
Attack technique description: Adversaries may leverage external-facing remote services to initially access and/or persist within a network. Remote services such as VPNs, Citrix, and other access mechanisms allow users to connect to internal enterprise network resources from external locations. There are often remote service gateways that manage connections and credential authentication for these services. Services such as [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006) and [VNC](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/005) can also be used externally.(Citation: MacOS VNC software for Remote Desktop)

Access to [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to use the service is often a requirement, which could be obtained through credential pharming or by obtaining the credentials from users after compromising the enterprise network.(Citation: Volexity Virtual Private Keylogging) Access to remote services may be used as a redundant or persistent access mechanism during an operation.

Access may also be gained through an exposed service that doesn’t require authentication. In containerized environments, this may include an exposed Docker API, Kubernetes API server, kubelet, or web application such as the Kubernetes dashboard.(Citation: Trend Micro Exposed Docker Server)(Citation: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, Containers, macOS

entities.name: EXTERNAL REMOTE SERVICES
entities.description: External Remote Services is an attack technique that allows adversaries to access and persist within a network through external-facing remote services like VPNs and Citrix.

entities.name: WINDOWS REMOTE MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Windows Remote Management is a service that can be used externally as part of the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VNC
entities.description: VNC is a remote access software that can be utilized externally in the context of the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VALID ACCOUNTS
entities.description: Valid Accounts are necessary for using remote services, often obtained through credential pharming or after compromising the enterprise network.

entities.name: DOCKER API
entities.description: The Docker API can be exposed in containerized environments, allowing access that may not require authentication.

entities.name: KUBERNETES API SERVER
entities.description: The Kubernetes API server can be exposed in containerized environments, providing access that may not require authentication.

entities.name: KUBELET
entities.description: Kubelet is a component in Kubernetes that can be exposed, allowing access that may not require authentication.

entities.name: KUBERNETES DASHBOARD
entities.description: The Kubernetes dashboard is a web application that can be exposed, allowing access that may not require authentication.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is one of the platforms that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: CONTAINERS
entities.description: Containers are environments that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is one of the platforms that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is one of the platforms that can be targeted by the External Remote Services attack technique.

entities.name: VOLEXITY VIRTUAL PRIVATE KEYLOGGING
entities.description: Volexity Virtual Private Keylogging is a method that can be used to obtain valid accounts by logging keystrokes to capture credentials.

entities.name: TREND MICRO EXPOSED DOCKER SERVER
entities.description: Trend Micro Exposed Docker Server refers to a situation where Docker services are exposed, potentially allowing unauthorized access.

entities.name: UNIT 42 HILDEGARD MALWARE
entities.description: Unit 42 Hildegard Malware is a type of malware that can exploit exposed services, including those related to Docker.

There are 4 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called SAML Tokens. Their names are as follows:
* Active Directory Configuration 
* Audit 
* User Account Management 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Active Directory Configuration
Mitigation method description: Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that involves managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: SAML TOKENS
entities.description: SAML Tokens are a type of security token used in authentication and authorization processes, which are the focus of the mitigation methods described.

* OSX/Shlayer

Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***

Software description: This piece of malware steals the content of the user's keychain while maintaining a permanent backdoor  (Citation: OSX Keydnap malware).
Platforms: macOS

Software description: [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) is a Trojan designed to install adware on macOS that was first discovered in 2018.(Citation: Carbon Black Shlayer Feb 2019)(Citation: Intego Shlayer Feb 2018)
Platforms: macOS

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification. Their names are as follows:
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Privileged Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions is a mitigation method that involves setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method that manages the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

entities.name: MAC
entities.description: Mac refers to macOS, an operating system that can also be impacted by file and directory permissions modification techniques.

chunk:
There are 3 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called PowerShell Profile. Their names are as follows:
* Code Signing 
* Restrict File and Directory Permissions 
* Software Configuration 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Software Configuration
Mitigation method description: Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

entities.name: CODESIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

entities.name: RESTRICTFILEANDDIRECTORYPERMISSIONS

entities.name: SOFTWARECONFIGURATION
entities.description: Software Configuration is a mitigation method that implements configuration changes to software to mitigate security risks associated with how the software operates.

entities.name: POWERSHELLPROFILE
entities.description: PowerShell Profile is an attack technique that can be mitigated using various methods to enhance security.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk:
There are 1 software using the attack technique called Startup Items. Their names are as follows:
* jRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: jRAT
Software description: [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor originally available for purchase in 2012. Variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) have been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform, similar to an online subscription model.(Citation: Kaspersky Adwind Feb 2016) (Citation: jRAT Symantec Aug 2018)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

entities.name: JRAT
entities.description: jRAT is a cross-platform, Java-based backdoor software that was originally available for purchase in 2012 and has been distributed via a software-as-a-service platform.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that jRAT operates on, among other platforms.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a widely used operating system that jRAT operates on, among other platforms.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple that jRAT operates on, among other platforms.

entities.name: ANDROID
entities.description: Android is a mobile operating system that jRAT operates on, among other platforms.

Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: SMOKEDHAM
Software description: [SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) is a Powershell-based .NET backdoor that was first reported in May 2021; it has been used by at least one ransomware-as-a-service affiliate.(Citation: FireEye Shining A Light on DARKSIDE May 2021)(Citation: FireEye SMOKEDHAM June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: SMOKEDHAM is a Powershell-based .NET backdoor software first reported in May 2021, used by at least one ransomware-as-a-service affiliate.

entities.name: RANSOMWARE-AS-A-SERVICE
entities.description: Ransomware-as-a-service is a business model that allows individuals to rent or purchase ransomware tools for malicious purposes.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform on which the SMOKEDHAM software operates.

entities.name: MAY 2021
entities.description: May 2021 is the date when SMOKEDHAM was first reported in the cybersecurity community.

chunk:
There are 2 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Embedded Payloads. Their names are as follows:
* Antivirus/Antimalware 
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Antivirus/Antimalware
Mitigation method description: Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

entities.name: ANTIVIRUS/ANTIMALWARE
entities.description: Antivirus/Antimalware is a mitigation method that uses signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems.

entities.name: MITIGATION METHODS
entities.description: Mitigation Methods refer to strategies or techniques employed to reduce or eliminate the impact of security threats, such as the attack technique called Embedded Payloads.

chunk:
There are 2 software using the attack technique called Process Argument Spoofing. Their names are as follows:
* Cobalt Strike
* SombRAT

The following content describes information about softwares. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: Cobalt Strike
Software description: [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as “adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors”. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)

In addition to its own capabilities, [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) leverages the capabilities of other well-known tools such as Metasploit and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: cobaltstrike manual)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: SombRAT
Software description: [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) is a modular backdoor written in C++ that has been used since at least 2019 to download and execute malicious payloads, including [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) ransomware.(Citation: BlackBerry CostaRicto November 2020)(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)(Citation: CISA AR21-126A FIVEHANDS May 2021)
Platforms: Windows

entities.description: FIVEHANDS is a ransomware that can be downloaded and executed by SombRAT.

chunk:
There are 5 mitigation methods that can mitigating the attack technique called Windows Service. Their names are as follows:
* Behavior Prevention on Endpoint 
* Operating System Configuration 
* Audit 
* Code Signing 
* User Account Management 

The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Code Signing
Mitigation method description: Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method that uses capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems, including suspicious processes, files, and API calls.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method that involves making configuration changes related to the operating system to enhance system security against various attack techniques.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method that involves performing audits or scans of systems, permissions, and configurations to identify potential weaknesses and vulnerabilities.

entities.name: CODE SIGNING
entities.description: Code Signing is a mitigation method that enforces binary and application integrity through digital signature verification to prevent the execution of untrusted code.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method that focuses on managing the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated with user accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: WINDOWS SERVICE
entities.description: Windows Service is an attack technique that can be mitigated through various methods to enhance security and prevent exploitation.)<|COMPLETE|>

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS
